snippet: On April 1, without hoopla, the city quietly became the largest in the nation to ensure that the vast majority of workers wouldn’t lose pay or their jobs if they or their close relatives became sick.
abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column observes that on April 1 New York City's paid sick leave law went into effect, making it largest city in nation to ensure that vast majority of workers would not lose pay or their jobs if they or close relatives become sick; notes that quiet, successful transition to new law is notable victory for Mayor Bill de Blasio, who significantly expanded law’s reach after taking office.
lead_paragraph: On April 1, without hoopla, the city quietly became the largest in the nation to ensure that the vast majority of workers wouldn’t lose pay or their jobs if they or their close relatives became sick.

headline.main: New York’s Paid Sick Leave Law Quietly Takes Effect
headline.print_headline: Paid Sick Leave Law Takes Effect in New York City, and Sky Doesn’t Fall
